close_symbols: OS_filesys_internal_record_t (type definition: fields device_name, virtual_mountpt, system_mountpt, flags)
explanation:
To decide whether OS_mount (directly or indirectly) violates the MISRA rule forbidding use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings the analyzer must inspect any code or macros that handle string inputs or perform name/string comparisons. Specifically:

- OS_CHECK_STRING (macro): This macro is invoked at the top of OS_mount to validate devname and mountpoint. It may perform string comparisons or length checks and could internally call memcmp (or another inappropriate comparison). Its definition must be examined to determine if memcmp is used on null-terminated strings.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): OS_mount uses this macro to obtain the filesys record from OS_filesys_table. The macro implementation may involve copying or comparing string fields or expand into code that references the structure layout; its expansion is needed to correctly interpret sizeof(...) uses and to see whether any string comparisons occur here.

- OS_filesys_internal_record_t (type definition): The sizeof(...) expressions in the OS_CHECK_STRING macro reference fields of this structure (device_name, virtual_mountpt). The analyzer needs the exact field types and sizes and whether these fields are null-terminated strings to know if any memcmp usage (elsewhere) is being applied to null-terminated data.

- OS_filesys_table (object/table definition): The table underlying OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET contains the stored names that may be compared against the input devname. The analyzer needs its layout and how names are stored (null-terminated or fixed buffers) to assess whether memcmp is used incorrectly when comparing them.

- OS_ObjectIdGetByName (implementation): OS_mount calls this function to find the object by name. Name lookup implementations frequently compare the supplied name to stored names; the implementation must be checked for any use of memcmp on null-terminated strings.

- OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch (implementation): This is the callee of OS_ObjectIdGetByName per the call-graph. If OS_ObjectIdGetByName delegates to this function to perform comparisons/search, that implementation also must be inspected for memcmp usage.

- OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl (implementation): Called by OS_mount when the filesys is in the correct state. It may perform additional string comparisons involving mount points or device names; its body must be checked for memcmp usage on null-terminated strings. The call-graph also shows it calls OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, so it may participate in name handling.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (implementation): Appears in the call chain for file system mount operations (called by FileSysMountVolume_Impl). It may access object tables or compare names; confirm whether memcmp is used here.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease (implementation) / OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish (called by release): While unlikely to compare strings, OS_mount calls OS_ObjectIdRelease unconditionally; if release or transaction finish code performs any validation or logging that compares names using memcmp, it should be inspected.

- memcmp (standard library function): The actual function must be checked (or references to it found) because the MISRA violation is specific to memcmp usage on null-terminated strings. The analyzer must confirm whether memcmp is called anywhere in the code paths reachable from OS_mount (including macros and called functions) and, if so, whether it is used to compare null-terminated strings.

Inspecting these symbols (macro expansions, structure layouts, and the implementations of the named functions) will allow a precise determination whether OS_mount or any code it invokes uses memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, thereby violating the MISRA rule.
